VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 1 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
This Corrective Action Plan was developed in response to the violations found
during the renewal licensing inspection of 2023. There was one violation involving
Rule 400.4113 Employee records. One of six employees was found not to have the
required three references in the personnel file. The facility has developed a
spreadsheet of new hires that review the HR personnel files for compliance
quarterly. Another staff is to provide oversite to ensure this review is taken place
and review the findings during quarterly supervision meetings. During this
investigation it was found that all new hire files reviewed (4) had the references as
required. Spreadsheet (check list) was completed in all new hire (4) files as outlined
in the corrective action plan.
Financial Overview
There are no financial concerns identified based on the review of the facility's
budget and the agency's financial audit.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
N/A
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator’s report outlines the actions taken for the corrective action
plan required during this reporting period. This involved the violation of a lack of
references for new employees. It is documented that the facility had 11 discharges
during the reporting period with 8 being planned and 3 unplanned. Two of the
unplanned discharges were the result of youth aggression towards staff which
resulted in the Juvenile Justice system becoming involved. One incident involved a
youth threatening a staff with a weapon and the other a youth breaking a staff’s
finger. The third youth was placed in a psychiatric hospital due to multiple intense
suicide attempts and suicidal ideation which required a higher level of care. This
report documents the average length of stay for youth is 75.33 days and the facility
has lengthened their program to 90 days with the hope of youth meeting the goal of
returning to the community rather than being removed to another residential
program. The focus has been on developing and supporting staff so the youth in
3

the program will see confident staff and staff’s positive ability to manage difficult
situations. This is being accomplished through trainings, staff meetings, and the
development of new intervention techniques. It is documented that all current staff
will be trained in motivational interviewing by the end of 2024. All staff are also
expected to be part of the facilities wellness activities, committees, and all facility
events. The program director is in the process of developing the pre-hire check list,
pre-hire requirements, and audit time frames and requirements. In regard to the
issue of continuous monitoring plan the facility has hired a Human Resources
Business Partner to assist the Operations Director with human resources and hiring
requirements. It is also documented the facility continues to seek ways to provide
the best clinical needs for the program and currently a part-time position is meeting
the needs since the program is maintain a low census.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Four direct care workers and one supervisor were interviewed. All reported a
positive outlook on the program and believed they are helping to make changes in
the youth served. All reported enjoying and finding significant benefits in the
training provided by administration and support being provided. None reported
having issues with the care of the youth.
Three youth were interviewed at the time of the inspection. All of the youth
interviewed reported a positive experience at the facility. They reported feeling safe
and enjoy having staff interact with them. The youth reported the program is
helping them learn new coping skills to overcome trauma in their lives.
Description of Agency Walk Through
This is a single story facility licensed for 6 youth with each having their own
bedroom. The bedrooms are furnished appropriately, and the facility is well
maintained. All plumbing is in working order and the facility was well stocked with
food and fresh items of food. All items (medication, cleaning supplies, and sharps)
required to be locked away from youth are locked as required and documentation
of medication being dispensed is accurate and appropriate. Overnight bedroom
checks are being documented as required and emergency drills have been
conducted per policy.
4

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. It is recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
